attributes.title: Intimate partner violence victims' intentions to seek help: the role of the Theory of Planned Behavior
attributes.description: Few studies have examined help-seeking behaviors by victims of intimate partner violence considering theoretical models that attempt to explain behavioral intentions. Furthermore, the literature on same-sex intimate partner violence is still scarce, and more research is needed to comprehend what may facilitate help-seeking. This research aims to apply the Theory of Planned Behavior (Ajzen, 1991) to better understand the intentions of victims of Intimate Partner Violence in different-sex and same-sex relationships to call a helpline.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This is a correlational study.

Firstly, participants will be asked whether they are or were in a relationship. If they are or were in a relationship, they will fill a questionnaire listing different types of abusive behaviors in intimate partner relationships.

If they list that they have been victims of any of the listed behaviors in their present relationship, they willl fill a questionnaire based on the main constructs of the Theory of Planned Behavior created specifically for this study. This questionnaire assesses participants' attitudes, subjective norm and perceived behavioral control to call a helpline in the following six months, as well as their preceding constructs (e.g. outcome evaluations and beliefs about outcome ocurrence for attitudes towards calling a hotline).

For participants who reported being victims in past relationships, an exploratory and adapted version of the questionnaire based on the Theory of Planned Behavior was administered.

Subsequently, only male participants will be asked to fill a gender role conflict measure. This instrument measures the degree to which men are in a state of internal discomfort/suffering due to the pressure to fulfil preconceived expectations about what it means to be a man.

Sociodemographic data will be collected, including additional control questions pertaining to knowledge of existing helplines, previous contacts to helplines and previous help-seeking experiences.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value: Data collection has begun on the 6th March 2020, but will continue over the coming weeks. Only researchers in our team have access to this data.

question.value:
The questionnaire is being administered online via the Qualtrics survey platform, and being shared trough social networks and mailing lists. At a later date, the survey will also be distributed by NGO's and GO's. Data collection will continue at least until 31st May 2020, at which point sample size requirements will be analyzed and possible extensions of the data collection period will be considered.

To be considered for analysis, participants must have had or have an intimate relationship,   be over 18 years old and understand and read Portuguese fluently.

Participants will be excluded from participating if they were never in an intimate relationship and if they are under 18 years old.

q11.value: We aim to collect 100 participants that self-identify as men (n=50) or women (n=50) who are/were victims in their different sex or same sex intimate relationships. Furthermore, we aim to collect an additional 50 men that have not been the targets of violence in their intimate relationships. These additional 50 men will allow for comparisons on the gender role conflict measure with men who have been targets of violence.

q12.value: The sample size was determined mainly by time and logistic constraints.

question.value:
Attitudes, subjective norm, perceived behavioral control and intentions to call a hotline; Gender role conflict and victimization status (victim vs not victim)

A summary of each measure is presented below:

Victimization in Intimate Partner Relationships - Conjugal Violence Inventory - 3 (Machado, Gonçalves & Matos, 2007). This instrument consists of 21 items, to which the participants
respond by reporting violent behaviors that occurred in the past year in the context
of their intimate relationships. For this study, it was adapted to consider the
abusive behaviors in current relationships and past relationships. Participants are asked to
report the frequency of their partner's abusive behaviors
("he/she never did it", "He/she did it once", and "He/she did it more than once"). One example of an item is "Threaten with weapons". Similarly to Costa, Machado and Antunes (2006), an item was added on the outing of sexual orientation. We also added another item about threatening to
prevent contact with dependents due to the perpetrator having their legal custody. According to the authors of the inventory, if the participant indicates that a behavior has happened at least once, he/she is considered a target of violence.

Attitudes, subjective norm, perceived behavior control and intentions to call a helpline - The construction of this questionnaire followed the recommendations based on the main constructs of the Theory of Planned Behavior (Ajzen, 2006). One example of an item is "Recognizing my situation is legitimate is",  rated from 1 -" Very Bad" to 7 - "Very Good".  For participants who indicate that violence occurred in a past relationship, an adapted version of this questionnaire is administered, and will be analyzed exploratorily. 

Gender role conflict - Gender Role Conflict Scale (Faria, 2002) - this scale assesses men's conflicts with their gender roles. It consists of 37 items that the participant scores using a Likert scale of 6 points (1- Strongly Disagree to 6 - Strongly Agree). It is consisted of four dimensions: Success, Power and Competition; Restricted Emotionality; Restricted Affective Behavior Among Men - Homophobia; Conflicts between Work and Family Relations. One example of an item is "It's hard for me to verbally express my love for another man". The higher the value obtained by adding the reported scores, the greater the
gender role conflict.

First we will report bivariate correlations between victim status and gender role conflict, attitudes, subjective norm, perceived behavioral control and intentions to call a helpline. 

Subsequently we will perform multiple regressions to assess the possible predictors of intentions to call a helpline, following the causal relationships predicted by the Theory of Planned Behavior (Ajzen, 1991). Gender role conflict will be tested as a possible predictor of attitudes and intentions to call a helpline, as literature on this topic indicates that men with higher gender role conflict seem to have more negative attitudes and lower intentions to seek help (O'Neil, 2008)

In the case that our previous analysis are affected by multicollinearity, we will consider othe analsyis without the collinear predictor(s) which correlates the least strongly with the dependent variable.

q20.value: Specific data pertaining to any given measure will be excluded if it is not filled completely or if any bias in the participation is detected.

q21.value: Specific data pertaining to any given measure will be excluded if it is not filled completely or if any bias in the participation is detected.

q22.value: For participants who indicate that violence occurred in a past relationship, an adapted version of the Theory of Planned Behavior is administered. The resulting data will be analyzed exploratorily.

attributes.title: Reducing Measurement Error in List Experiments

q1.value: Reducing Measurement Error in List Experiments

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: The list experiment is one of the most important tools in social science for eliciting truthful responses to sensitive questions. Under some basic assumptions the list experiment can provide an unbiased estimate of the share of affirmative answers to a sensitive question in the population of interest. A drawback of the standard design is that this estimate tends to have high variance. Recent studies also suggest that non-strategic respondent error stemming from inattentive respondents can be especially problematic in list experiments. Inattentive respondents can both further increase variance and substantially increase bias in the estimate of interest. This project aims at developing and testing design-based solutions and recommendations to minimize respondent error in list experiments. We explore four different techniques to increase the average respondent attention in the sample: Instructional manipulation checks; Factual manipulation checks; the inclusion of a Placebo Statement in the control list; and the inclusion of an Audit Warning to increase respondent attentiveness. We discuss the upsides and challenges with respect to each strategy as applied to the list experiment specifically. To empirically evaluate the different methods we design several list experiments where the true population quantity of the item of interest (the “sensitive” item) is known. We use these to test the accuracy of the list experiment in estimating the known quantity, and to explore the potential of different methods to improve the quality of provided responses. The pre-analysis plan also contains hypotheses and analysis strategies for two additional papers based on the same study. These are presented in two separate sections at the end of the document.

q19.value: At least 4000, with the aim of reaching 5000. Data collection will be handled by Luc.id.

q27.value: The online survey will be distributed by Luc.id.

attributes.title: Personal similarity at the workplace
attributes.description: This project investigates the effects of perceived similarity on liking on work contexts. We investigate the moderating effects of job desirability on this relationship. This second study explores whether the effect of similarity on liking prevails when similarity is perceived with oneself or with another member of the same organization (work colleague).

q1.value: Jimena Ramirez-Marin, Adrian Barragan Diaz, Mario Pandelaere

q2.value: 1) Perceived similarity will increase liking 2) The effect of perceived similarity on liking will be moderated by job desirability. Similar others in undesirable jobs will be liked less than similar others in desirable jobs. 3) Similarity to oneself will increase liking above and beyond similarity with a colleague.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This is a factorial design and the factors are 2 similarity (me vs colleague) x 2 job positions (desirable and undesirable). It is a between subjects design. No counterbalancing is required. All participants will be randomly assigned to conditions.

q7.value: We use Qualtrics, and the software uses simple randomization for the blocks containing the manipulations.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q9.value: We pre-tested the manipulation of similar to colleague as this hasn't been used in previous research. We use the data from this pilot study to calculate the effect size and sample size.

question.value: We will use the platform Mechanical Turk to collect the data.

q11.value: The number of participants will be 136.

q12.value: We performed an a priori analysis using G*power. The parameters were t-test mean comparison for two independent groups. Effect size = .695, error probability = .05, power = .95 and allocation ratio = 1. We calculated 20% more to check attention of Mturkers. Final sample is 112 +24=136.

q13.value: There is no stopping rule. We have full control over the number of participants.

question.value: All the materials for data collection are presented in the word document attached.

We used 3 items to measure similarity and 5 items to measure job desirability and two items to measure liking. 

The similarity items were adapted from: Tepper, Bennett J., Sherry E. Moss, and Michelle K. Duffy (2011), "Predictors of Abusive Supervision: Supervisor Perceptions of Deep-Level Dissimilarity, Relationship Conflict, and Subordinate Performance", Academy of Management Journal, 54, 279-294.

This candidate and I are similar in terms of our outlook, perspective, and values. 
This candidate and I analyze problems in a similar way. 
This candidate and I think alike in terms of coming up with a similar solution for a problem. 

The job desirability items were adapted from: Schleicher, Deidra (2004), "Reexamining the Job Satisfaction- Performance Relationship: The Complexity of Attitudes", Journal of Applied Psychology, 89, 165-177.

I am enthusiastic about the XX job. 
I would feel very satisfied with XX the job.
Each minute as XX would seem like it would never end. 
I could find real enjoyment in XX job. 
I consider the XX job rather unpleasant.

To measure liking we adapted the job satisfaction single item measure from Lee, Tae Heon, Barry Gerhart, and Ingo Weller (2008), "Understanding voluntary turnover: Path-specific job satisfaction effects and the importance of unsolicited job offers", Academy of Management Journal, 51, 651-671. We used two different scales of response (happy and positive). 

How would you feel about that candidate being hired as XX? (happy-unhappy) 
How would you feel about that candidate being hired as XX? (positive-negative)

We measured how similar they perceived they were with the colleague. 
How similar do you think you are to your colleague from work (same as hobby)?

We kept the single item measures used in Study 1 for consistency.
All items shown above were averaged to create scales. Except for single item measures.

We plan to conduct a t-test to check for effects of manipulation on our perceived similarity items. We will also conduct a regression analysis to test the indirect effects of job desirability on the relationship between similarity and liking.

q18.value: We plan to have a coding scheme for our manipulation variable with the following indicators high similarity=1 low similarity -1.

q19.value: We will be using one tailed test for the hypothesis testing.

q20.value: We will exclude outliers. Outlier is a point which falls more than 1.5 times the interquartile range above the third quartile or below the first quartile.

q21.value: If this is system missing data, we will remove it from the sample.

q22.value: We do not plan to conduct exploratory analysis as the dependent variables are only those necessary to test our hypothesis.

attributes.title: Different Arrays of Digital Health Interventions for Frail Persons: a Scoping Review Protocol
attributes.description: The use of digital health technologies has been on the rising trend over the decades. Different types of digital health interventions have been widely used in diagnosis, care and data management of health sectors. At the same time there is an overgrowing research work on digital health interventions, however, a few reviews have been done with the focus on the frail population, who are at risk or prone to infection, disease or disability. This scoping review will be the first to compile digital health interventions for frail persons and observe the applicability of these interventions for the study population

summary.value: The use of digital health technologies has been on the rising trend over the decades. Different types of digital health interventions have been widely used in diagnosis, care and data management of health sectors. At the same time there is an overgrowing research work on digital health interventions, however, a few reviews have been done with the focus on the frail population, who are at risk or prone to infection, disease or disability.  This scoping review will be the first to compile digital health interventions for frail persons and observe the applicability of these interventions

attributes.title: BIOREMEDIATION-COCKTAIL FOR ECO-RECOVERY OF IMPACTED ENVIRONMENT UPDATED
attributes.description: This is a collection of raw and extended data for this study that optimised bioremediation cocktail for recovery of impacted environment.

summary.value: There is different from the earlier version as the multiple files in xls got lost on conversion to csv and has been taken care of here

registration_responses.summary: There is different from the earlier version as the multiple files in xls got lost on conversion to csv and has been taken care of here

data.value: Yes, we already collected the data.

other.value:
In order to increase the precision of any estimated treatment effects, we will run additional analyses with covariates included. We plan to include age and liberal ideology as covariates, with the former indexing a possible inverse association between positive scores on our outcomes and older age, and the latter indexing a possible positive correlation between our outcomes and progressive political views. 

In addition, we intend to use this lab study as part of a mini meta-analysis of all three experiments that are part of this research project. 

Moreover, since across the previous two studies we have consistently uncovered positive coefficients for assignment to the Latinx condition (in line with our argument), we will use one-tailed tests of significance to assess our directional hypothesis here (i.e., assignment to Latinx condition causes participants to report more favorability toward LGBTQ groups and to express greater support for Pro-LGBTQ policy.

Finally, we intend to conduct an exploratory analysis of nativity’s moderating effect on our treatments. That is, we will analyze the extent to which being born in the United States (or not) moderates the impact of our treatments on our outcomes.

sample.value: Our experiment is embedded in an omnibus survey conducted across two public university campuses in southern California. This participant pool is sustained by faculty colleagues who incentivize student participation through a modicum of extra credit. We anticipate yielding about 300 Latino participants.

analyses.value:
We plan to scale the favorability ratings into indices of average favorability toward LGBTQ groups and average favorability toward people of color. In addition, we plan to scale responses to the policy items into an index of average support for pro-LGBTQ policy. 

We will then regress each of these outcomes on dichotomous indicators of each treatment condition, with the control group as the omitted category. We will parallel these results with corresponding t-tests. Finally, since this is the last study in a set of three, we will use the results here to meta-analyze our results from all of our available studies.

outliers.value:
We will consider an outlier to be any response to our outcome(s) that is more than 3 standard deviation from its mean. In addition, we will consider outliers those participants who report 10% or more missing values in our outcomes. If we find that this missingness is non-random, then we will not analyze the data further. However, if the degree of missingness appears to be random, we will simply analyze the data by excluding those cases that exceed our missingness threshold. 

Moreover, since this study is focused on Latinx identity, we plan to only analyze Latino adults who participated in our lab study.

dependent.value:
Using a scale from 1-very unfavorable to 7- very favorable, participants will rate the following groups, presented in randomized order: Transgender individuals, Gays, Lesbians, African Americans, Asian Americans, Native Americans, and Whites. 

Following these favorability ratings, participants used a scale from 1-strongly disagree to 7-strongly agree to complete the following statements, asked in randomized order: 

-Making most public restrooms gender neutral. 
 	
-Encouraging the use of gender-neutral language in government proceedings. 

-Increasing penalties for hate crimes toward LGBT individuals. 

-Collecting public data on the gender orientation of California residents.

conditions.value: There are four experimental conditions. In each condition, participants are asked to write 3 attributes that make them 1) a unique individual; 2) Hispanic; 3) Latino; or 4) Latinx.

hypothesis.value:
We assess whether Latinx identity is a distinctive form of group attachment among Latino adults. To this end, we designed a lab study with four conditions. In each condition, participants are asked to write 3 attributes that make them 1) a unique individual; 2) Hispanic; 3) Latino; or 4) Latinx. Post-treatment, all participants report their favorability toward a variety of racial/ethnic minority and LGBTQ groups. In addition, all participants are asked to report their support for pro-LGBTQ policy. 

Insofar as Latinx identity is a distinctive attachment, we expect that relative to the control, participants assigned to the Latinx condition will report more favorability toward LGBTQ groups and stronger support for pro-LGBTQ policy. We will use the favorability ratings of racial/ethnic minorities to assess whether favorability ratings spill over onto non-LGBTQ groups.

registration_responses.data: Yes, we already collected the data.
registration_responses.name: Latinx ID
registration_responses.other:
In order to increase the precision of any estimated treatment effects, we will run additional analyses with covariates included. We plan to include age and liberal ideology as covariates, with the former indexing a possible inverse association between positive scores on our outcomes and older age, and the latter indexing a possible positive correlation between our outcomes and progressive political views. 

In addition, we intend to use this lab study as part of a mini meta-analysis of all three experiments that are part of this research project. 

Moreover, since across the previous two studies we have consistently uncovered positive coefficients for assignment to the Latinx condition (in line with our argument), we will use one-tailed tests of significance to assess our directional hypothesis here (i.e., assignment to Latinx condition causes participants to report more favorability toward LGBTQ groups and to express greater support for Pro-LGBTQ policy.

Finally, we intend to conduct an exploratory analysis of nativity’s moderating effect on our treatments. That is, we will analyze the extent to which being born in the United States (or not) moderates the impact of our treatments on our outcomes.
registration_responses.sample: Our experiment is embedded in an omnibus survey conducted across two public university campuses in southern California. This participant pool is sustained by faculty colleagues who incentivize student participation through a modicum of extra credit. We anticipate yielding about 300 Latino participants.
registration_responses.analyses:
We plan to scale the favorability ratings into indices of average favorability toward LGBTQ groups and average favorability toward people of color. In addition, we plan to scale responses to the policy items into an index of average support for pro-LGBTQ policy. 

We will then regress each of these outcomes on dichotomous indicators of each treatment condition, with the control group as the omitted category. We will parallel these results with corresponding t-tests. Finally, since this is the last study in a set of three, we will use the results here to meta-analyze our results from all of our available studies.
registration_responses.outliers:
We will consider an outlier to be any response to our outcome(s) that is more than 3 standard deviation from its mean. In addition, we will consider outliers those participants who report 10% or more missing values in our outcomes. If we find that this missingness is non-random, then we will not analyze the data further. However, if the degree of missingness appears to be random, we will simply analyze the data by excluding those cases that exceed our missingness threshold. 

Moreover, since this study is focused on Latinx identity, we plan to only analyze Latino adults who participated in our lab study.
registration_responses.dependent:
Using a scale from 1-very unfavorable to 7- very favorable, participants will rate the following groups, presented in randomized order: Transgender individuals, Gays, Lesbians, African Americans, Asian Americans, Native Americans, and Whites. 

Following these favorability ratings, participants used a scale from 1-strongly disagree to 7-strongly agree to complete the following statements, asked in randomized order: 

-Making most public restrooms gender neutral. 
 	
-Encouraging the use of gender-neutral language in government proceedings. 

-Increasing penalties for hate crimes toward LGBT individuals. 

-Collecting public data on the gender orientation of California residents.
registration_responses.conditions: There are four experimental conditions. In each condition, participants are asked to write 3 attributes that make them 1) a unique individual; 2) Hispanic; 3) Latino; or 4) Latinx.
registration_responses.hypothesis:
We assess whether Latinx identity is a distinctive form of group attachment among Latino adults. To this end, we designed a lab study with four conditions. In each condition, participants are asked to write 3 attributes that make them 1) a unique individual; 2) Hispanic; 3) Latino; or 4) Latinx. Post-treatment, all participants report their favorability toward a variety of racial/ethnic minority and LGBTQ groups. In addition, all participants are asked to report their support for pro-LGBTQ policy. 

Insofar as Latinx identity is a distinctive attachment, we expect that relative to the control, participants assigned to the Latinx condition will report more favorability toward LGBTQ groups and stronger support for pro-LGBTQ policy. We will use the favorability ratings of racial/ethnic minorities to assess whether favorability ratings spill over onto non-LGBTQ groups.

attributes.title: Developing Artificial Intelligence to Process Correspondence to Primary Care:  Baseline interviews and user requirements
attributes.description:
UK GP practices processes hundreds of letters regarding their patients every day, usually using electronic document management software. This work is usually done by General Practitioners (GPs), however a more efficient alternative could be to harness advances in machine learning and artificial intelligence (AI). 
This qualitative study aims to provide understanding of how letters regarding patients are currently processed within UK GP practices and staff perspectives of how AI might be used in this process. We will interview staff in GP practices and conduct usability tests to answer our main research question, which is: how do UK GP practices currently process letters regarding patients and how might AI be used in this process?

Objectives are to understand:
1.	How UK GP practices currently process letters.
2.	The challenges and good practices when processing letters in UK primary care.
3.	If automation / AI could help, and if so how it could be designed for optimal impact.

summary.value: This registration contains the ethically approved research study protocol.

registration_responses.summary: This registration contains the ethically approved research study protocol.

attributes.title: Enhenced Rocovery After paediatric surgery : a meta analysis of published studies
attributes.description: Meta analysis of studies describing ERAS in children and infants

summary.value: The current meta analysis will explore available evidences about the ERAS in children. The primary outcome of the study will the the duration of postoperative stay. Secondry outcomes will be: postoperative complications, major complication and hospital readmission at 30 days after surgery.

registration_responses.summary: The current meta analysis will explore available evidences about the ERAS in children. The primary outcome of the study will the the duration of postoperative stay. Secondry outcomes will be: postoperative complications, major complication and hospital readmission at 30 days after surgery.
